item.title: Germany may have no choice but to take on the big role the EU needs it to play https://t.co/jDI21Y0dD0
This week's cartoon from KAL: https://t.co/ATHqTKQTeG https://t.co/R4Bx3Vv9M2

“If you start an operation on flawed assumptions, inevitably, your planning is inadequate—your command and control won’t work.” General Sir Nick Carter joins “The Economist Asks” to explain how Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has not gone to plan https://t.co/cs9z41wW0o

Joe Biden and his foreign policy team should “take the credit for this impressive and united NATO response to Putin’s agressions”. Hear more from @JamesMAstill on our “Checks and Balance” podcast https://t.co/kBemLPAsbv https://t.co/1pczvCByUw

From the start, Vladimir Putin has made clear that this is a war of escalation. He threatens to be more destructive even if that means resorting to a nuclear weapon. The world must stand up to him.
Our cover this week ⬇️

“If there is anything in Russia you can be proud of right now, it is those people who have been detained,” Alexei Navalny, Russia’s jailed opposition leader, wrote in a statement https://t.co/6RmxdAgLEM
Nobel laureates have called upon the Russian government to stop its invasion of Ukraine and withdraw its military forces https://t.co/mRukuP20II
Rome’s new mayor managed to locate tens of millions of unspent euros in the city’s accounts—money he spent on fixing the ravaged streets https://t.co/NxOAHSDKSV

The West’s measures have triggered chaos in Russia’s $1.6trn economy. This will cause alarm around the world, not least in China, which will recalculate the costs of a war over Taiwan https://t.co/TeBEUKiTJo

“It does not make me happy that countries in my region were right to warn others of the Russian threat,” writes Lithuania’s prime minister @IngridaSimonyte. “I wish we had been proven wrong instead” https://t.co/163X2qZ9lW
The level of Ukrainian resistance has shocked Russian commanders https://t.co/qYAosq2Ns9
The military difficulties the Russians are having may lead China to rethink the feasibility of an invasion across the Taiwan strait https://t.co/coCAfTtX03

“He’s been absolutely phenomenal in raising national morale. There’s admiration for what he’s done and is achieving.” General Sir Nick Carter assesses President Volodymyr Zelensky’s leadership during the war in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/gCQE25bmkH https://t.co/p2nbjNbjJU
In recent years attitudes in Lithuania towards China have been hardening. China’s refusal to condemn Russia for invading Ukraine has not helped https://t.co/NcjkKQWSRP
No major economy in the modern world has ever been hit so hard by sanctions https://t.co/nfzDfWRaFs
Russian fuel, engineering and other supply units have struggled to keep up with frontline forces, leaving vehicles stranded on the road https://t.co/8NDsEQpMvn
The 23 short stories in “My Pen is the Wing of a Bird” were written by 18 Afghan women and translated from the original Dari and Pashto by other Afghans https://t.co/OZgGUAazKy
Fox News is still airing pro-Putin commentary, and Donald Trump still praises the Russian leader https://t.co/xwI51i8P1t
In a country fast turning totalitarian, there is plenty of room for bravery. More than 1m people in Russia have signed a petition against the war https://t.co/oik3LlLdTO

Viral videos of defiant Ukrainians have changed how many Taiwanese see their future selves. A slogan coursing through Taiwanese social media is “Ukraine today, Taiwan tomorrow!” https://t.co/T8VCQG3NqP
The fog of war remains thick. Russia may have chosen to slow down its movement in order to synchronise its various advances on Kyiv https://t.co/KQS42Et0rK
Venezuela’s government, far from trying to stop environmental plunder, is encouraging it https://t.co/Rc8s5sisyY
Western sanctions have created an economic storm. Many Russians will soon struggle to afford what they need to survive https://t.co/FyttKh2bTI
Watching a prolonged and bloody siege of Kyiv would further enrage public opin­ion in large parts of the world, and could thus lead to even harsher sanctions on Russia https://t.co/abqI8rjh3C
Dozens of Nobel laureates voice “their support for the Ukrainian people and the free and independent state of Ukraine as it faces Russian aggression” https://t.co/Iwa6H9p4IG
Ever since Donald Trump rose to the top of the Republican primaries in 2016, conservative talking-heads have praised the Russian leader’s vigour and acuity https://t.co/Rj0KNhUXVh

He is committing war crimes in Ukraine. At home, he is subjecting his people to the harshest state terror since Stalin. And to the West, he is issuing threats of nuclear war. The world must stand up to him https://t.co/s3epgLN17g

“The West never dared to question Vladimir Putin’s legitimacy out loud. Democracies die in silence, they say. In silence, too, dictatorships grow.” Lithuania’s prime minister @IngridaSimonyte explains why the invasion was “bound to happen” https://t.co/ZhfWs7ygtz
The defence industry looks set for bigger business https://t.co/zToES4JBHO
Xi Jinping faces a dilemma. Though he does not want Vladimir Putin to fail, helping him means being spattered by his carnage https://t.co/C15FyLA9zt

Russia, one economist says, is sliding back into the dark post­-So­viet 1990s, the dismal period which Vladimir Putin says was forced on it by the West and from which he liberated it https://t.co/OgQKwiCe7i
Vladimir Putin, so intent on bringing Ukraine under his control, is neglecting the problems facing Russians at home https://t.co/ZvGStFDhGf
A Russian military convoy, no less than 60km long, has been moving at snail’s pace towards the capital. It epitomises Russia’s plodding approach to the war so far. Read why ⬇️

“If you look at people who’ve been in power for as long as Putin has...going into an election is pretty slim—the chances are more like he gets toppled by a protest.” Russia expert Fiona Hill examines Vladimir Putin’s future, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/5QdorpMTxY https://t.co/uWTWr3QrWn
Russia may have tried to build a “fortress economy”, but it is the West that currently looks financially secure https://t.co/pfXWeTWn4J

The world must be willing to bleed Vladimir Putin’s regime of the resources that enable him to wage war and abuse his own people even if that imposes costs on Western economies https://t.co/6DZXuLTqyY
A Russian military convoy, no less than 60km long, has been moving at snail’s pace towards the capital. It epitomises Russia’s plodding approach to the war so far https://t.co/djkwGpno4r
It has been more than a week since Russia invaded Ukraine. We recap the war so far 👇 https://t.co/w89HmcBBzB https://t.co/oGVL6dgpjl
Kyiv looks likely to be encircled and then presumably besieged https://t.co/76sgGu3uE5
Since late last year, Lithuania has become the target of the most sweeping sanctions any country has faced for upsetting China’s Communist Party https://t.co/DyU9wI2MwL
Just one of six reactors at Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant is running at 60% capacity. Energy shortages have the potential to cause great suffering in Ukraine https://t.co/xKvixbrzuD
One nurse is caring for ten sick babies on her own. Her colleagues have either fled or can’t get to work. @1843mag steps inside Ukraine’s largest paediatric unit https://t.co/N4xcY9PdqU

France, and its influence over the EU, matters more than it has for a long time. The election is worth watching closely. To keep up with the race, bookmark our hub on the French election https://t.co/X8PZZxDEQU https://t.co/toe6T7ox3s

From the start, Vladimir Putin has made clear that this is a war of escalation. He threatens to be more destructive even if that means resorting to a nuclear weapon. The world must stand up to him.
Our cover this week ⬇️
One nurse is caring for ten sick babies on her own. Her colleagues have either fled or can’t get to work. @1843mag steps inside Ukraine’s largest paediatric unit https://t.co/aOowcei5mt
The more powerful sanctions are, the greater the risk of collateral damage, particularly when targeted regimes are indifferent to the suffering of citizens https://t.co/frqTjb4LXM
Russia may be using control of Ukraine’s nuclear power plants to “leverage terror over Europe”, says an energy lawyer formerly in Kyiv https://t.co/tpIeJnt2hl
NATO has rejected Ukraine’s demand for no-fly zones. What sounds like a humanitarian measure is also an act of war. We explain why https://t.co/RTEiXHbWz5
Defence spending will now rise more rapidly and that 2% of GDP will become a de facto minimum across NATO, reckons Citigroup https://t.co/RZNLnuSSw2

“There's nothing special about me. The only thing that’s different in my story is that my father did not stop me.”
To mark #IWD2022, @Malala and @zannymb discuss how to improve the lives of girls everywhere.
Subscribers can sign up to watch here: https://t.co/Cg6G1x8syd https://t.co/Uzv8spLrau
